case_name: Appellants v. Income-tax Officer, Bellari, Special Circle, Bangalore

facts.text: Appeal filed with special leave of Supreme Court against High Court of Mysore decision

anchor.surface_text: HIDAYATULLAH, J. - This appeal has been filed with the special leave of this companyrt against a decision of the High Court of Mysore,

facts.text: High Court of Mysore dismissed in limine application under article 226 by appellants

anchor.surface_text: by which it dismissed in limine an application by the appellants under article 226 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition or some other appropriate writ against the Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Application under Art 226 for writ of prohibition against Income-tax Officer, Bellari, Special Circle, Bangalore

anchor.surface_text: by which it dismissed in limine an application by the appellants under article 226 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition or some other appropriate writ against the Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Assessment year 1948-49

anchor.surface_text: Bellari, Special Circle, Bangalore. The facts of the case are as follows. For the assessment year 1948-49,

facts.text: Appellants failed to file return within prescribed time

anchor.surface_text: the appellants failed to file a return within the prescribed time and the Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice under section 28(1)(a) to show cause why penalty should be imposed

anchor.surface_text: acting under section 28 1  a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, issued a numberice to them to show cause why penalty should number be imposed.

facts.text: Appellants filed written reply to the notice

anchor.surface_text: In answer to this numberice, the appellants filed a written reply and the Income-tax Officer proceeded

facts.text: Income-tax Officer levied penalty of Rs. 16,000 without affording hearing as required by section 28(3)

anchor.surface_text: to levy a penalty of Rs. 16,000, without affording a hearing to them as required by the third sub-section of section 28 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appeal taken to Appellate Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken up in appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of number granted to the appellants,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held order defective, set aside order, directed refund of penalty if recovered

anchor.surface_text: held that the order was defective. He, therefore, set aside that order and directed the refund of the penalty if it had been recovered.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued further notice to appellants to appear for opportunity of being heard

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the order, the Income-tax officer issued a further numberice calling upon the appellants to appear before him, so that they might be given an opportunity of being heard.

facts.text: ITO intimated that if no appearance, would proceed on written statement filed earlier

anchor.surface_text: He also intimated that if numberappearance was made, then he would proceed to determine the question of penalty, taking into companysideration only the written statement which had been filed earlier.

facts.text: Before ITO could decide, appellants filed petition under Art 226

anchor.surface_text: Before, however, the Income-tax Officer companyld decide the case, the appellants filed a petition under article 226 of the companystitution for the issuance of the writs mentioned above.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petition in limine holding contention may be raised before Income-tax authorities

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed in limine by the High Court holding that the companytention raised by the appellants may perhaps be raised before the Income-tax authorities.

facts.text: Appellants applied for special leave to Supreme Court, leave granted

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon applied for special leave to this companyrt and leave having been granted, this matter companyes up before us.

facts.text: Requirements of section 28(1)(a) completely fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: There is numberquestion here that the requirements of section 28 1  a  of the Income-tax Act were number companypletely fulfilled.

facts.text: Appellants did not file return as required by law, attracting clause (a) of sub-section (1) of section 28

anchor.surface_text: If the appellants had number filed their return, as they were required by law to do, the omission would attract clause  a  of sub-section  1  of section 28.

facts.text: Section 28(3) requires reasonable opportunity of being heard before imposing penalty

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of section 28, however, requires that the penalty shall number be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

facts.text: Opportunity of hearing denied to appellants, vitiating ITO's order

anchor.surface_text: This opportunity was denied to the appellants and, therefore, the order of the Income-tax officer was vitiated by an illegality which supervened,

facts.text: AAC order pointed out illegality and directed refund if recovered

anchor.surface_text: number at the initial stage of the proceedings, but during the companyrse of it. The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered,

facts.text: AAC order interpreted as correcting error, allowing ITO to continue from stage of illegality

anchor.surface_text: cannot but be interpreted as companyrecting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to companytinue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred.

facts.text: No express remand necessary for ITO to continue

anchor.surface_text: No express remand for this purpose, as is companytended, was necessary.

facts.text: Kerala HC decision in Jos Chacko Poothokaran v. ITO cited, but distinguished

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to a decision of a learned single judge of the Kerala High Court reported in Jos Chacko Poothokaran v. Income-tax Officer, Ernakulam Circle, in which, in similar circumstances,

facts.text: In Kerala case, held that AAC order final since no appeal by CIT to Tribunal under s.33(2)

anchor.surface_text: it has been held that since an appeal was number taken by the Commissioner of Income-tax to the Appellate Tribunal under sub-section  2  of section 33, the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner became final

facts.text: Supreme Court holds reason in Kerala case beside the point

anchor.surface_text: and the Income-tax Officer companyld numberlonger proceed to reassess the penalty. The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point.

facts.text: AAC vacated order due to illegality during proceedings

anchor.surface_text: What the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did was to vacate the order and direct refund of the penalty in view of an illegality which had occurred during the companyrse of the assessment proceedings.

facts.text: On receipt of AAC order, ITO open to take up matter from point of illegality

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the record it was open to the Income-tax officer to take up the matter from the point at which the illegality supervened and to companyrect his proceedings.

facts.text: Appellants contended proceedings only during course of assessment, which are concluded

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in the companyrse of the statement of the case by the appellants that such proceedings companyld only be taken during the companyrse of assessment proceedings and those proceedings are companycluded.

facts.text: Show cause notice did not cease to be operative despite AAC pointing out illegality

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the numberice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

facts.text: Proceedings not started can be continued as during course of assessment, relating back to first notice

anchor.surface_text: That numberice having remained still to be disposed of, the proceedings number started can be described as during the companyrse of the assessment proceedings, because the action will relate back to the time when the first numberice was issued.

facts.text: ITO within jurisdiction to continue proceedings from stage of illegality and assess penalty if required

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Income-tax Officer is well within his jurisdiction to companytinue the proceedings from the stage at which the illegality has occurred and to assess the appellants to a penalty, if any, which the circumstances of the case may require.

issues.text: Whether an express remand by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was necessary for the Income-tax Officer to continue the proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred

anchor.surface_text: cannot but be interpreted as correcting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred. No express remand for this purpose, as is contended, was necessary. Our attention was drawn to a decision of a learned single judge of the Kerala High Court reported in Jos Chacko Poothokaran v. Income-tax Officer, Ernakulam Circle, in which, in similar circumstances, it has been held that since an appeal was number taken by the Commissioner of Income-tax to the Appellate Tribunal under sub-section  2  of section 33, the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner became final

issues.text: Whether the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner became final and the Income-tax Officer could no longer proceed to reassess the penalty since no appeal was taken under sub-section (2) of section 33

anchor.surface_text: it has been held that since an appeal was number taken by the Commissioner of Income-tax to the Appellate Tribunal under sub-section  2  of section 33, the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner became final and the Income-tax Officer could no longer proceed to reassess the penalty. The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point.

issues.text: Whether penalty proceedings could only be taken during the course of assessment proceedings and those proceedings are concluded after the Appellate Assistant Commissioner's order

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in the course of the statement of the case by the appellants that such proceedings could only be taken during the course of assessment proceedings and those proceedings are concluded. In our opinion, the notice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer is within his jurisdiction to continue the penalty proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred and impose penalty

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Income-tax Officer is well within his jurisdiction to continue the proceedings from the stage at which the illegality has occurred and to assess the appellants to a penalty, if any, which the circumstances of the case may require.

arguments.claim: The order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the illegality, corrected the error, and left it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred

arguments.claim: What the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did was to vacate the order due to illegality during assessment proceedings and it was open to ITO to take up the matter from the point of illegality upon receipt of the record

anchor.surface_text: The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point. What the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did was to vacate the order and direct refund of the penalty in view of an illegality which had occurred during the companyrse of the assessment proceedings. On receipt of the record it was open to the Income-tax officer to take up the matter from the point at which the illegality supervened and to companyrect his proceedings.

arguments.claim: The show cause notice issued under section 28(1)(a) did not cease to be operative merely because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the illegality which vitiated the proceeding after lawful initiation

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the numberice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

holdings.text: There is no question here that the requirements of section 28(1)(a) of the Income-tax Act were completely fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberquestion here that the requirements of section 28 1  a  of the Income-tax Act were number companypletely fulfilled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory requirements to undisputed facts of notice issuance after failure to file return.

holdings.text: Sub-section (3) of section 28 requires that the penalty shall not be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of section 28, however, requires that the penalty shall number be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of mandatory procedural requirement under s.28(3).

holdings.text: This opportunity was denied to the appellants and, therefore, the order of the Income-tax officer was vitiated by an illegality which supervened not at the initial stage of the proceedings, but during the course of it.

anchor.surface_text: This opportunity was denied to the appellants and, therefore, the order of the Income-tax officer was vitiated by an illegality which supervened, number at the initial stage of the proceedings, but during the companyrse of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.28(3) to facts showing no hearing provided before penalty levy.

holdings.text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, cannot but be interpreted as correcting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, cannot but be interpreted as companyrecting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to companytinue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretive reading of AAC order as curative rather than final termination.

holdings.text: No express remand for this purpose, as is contended, was necessary.

holdings.text: What the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did was to vacate the order and direct refund of the penalty in view of an illegality which had occurred during the course of the assessment proceedings. On receipt of the record it was open to the Income-tax officer to take up the matter from the point at which the illegality supervened and to correct his proceedings.

On receipt of the record it was open to the Income-tax officer to take up the matter from the point at which the illegality supervened and to companyrect his proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: AAC action seen as vacating defective order, preserving jurisdiction to rectify.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the notice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should not be imposed on them did not cease to be operative because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original notice remains valid post-set-aside despite supervening illegality.

holdings.text: That notice having remained still to be disposed of, the proceedings not started can be described as during the course of the assessment proceedings, because the action will relate back to the time when the first notice was issued.

anchor.surface_text: That numberice having remained still to be disposed of, the proceedings number started can be described as during the companyrse of the assessment proceedings, because the action will relate back to the time when the first numberice was issued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of relation back maintains continuity of proceedings.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the Income-tax Officer is well within his jurisdiction to continue the proceedings from the stage at which the illegality has occurred and to assess the appellants to a penalty, if any, which the circumstances of the case may require.
